It gave me nightmares for weeks: The movie’s title refers to an experimental spaceship that could create artificial black holes through which to travel, making interstellar trips trivial.

1.caption: What might be more puzzling than the innards of a black hole is the trouble of defining one in the first place.

2621318795.resolved_title: An Orbit Map of the Solar System
2621318795.excerpt: This week’s map shows the orbits of more than 18000 asteroids in the solar system. This includes everything we know of that’s over 10km in diameter - about 10000 asteroids - as well as 8000 randomized objects of unknown size.

2.credit: the ribbon thickness shows the orbit movement in the z axis
2.caption: Some early Python experiments on visualizing orbital paths. In these drafts I used data from the moons of Neptune, Jupiter, and Saturn, because a few dozen moons are much easier to manage than several thousand asteroids. Although I didn’t end up using the code, I still really like the orbit ribbon diagram

2550090798.resolved_title: One night of telescope time rules out black hole/dark matter idea
2550090798.excerpt: Much of the Universe behaves as if there's more matter there than we can see. Dark matter explains this by positing that there's matter present that we can't see, and evidence has piled up in favor of this idea.

3641916014.resolved_title: Behold the Magnetar, nature’s ultimate superweapon
3641916014.excerpt: If you think black holes are the scariest things in the Universe, I have something to share with you. There are balls of dead matter no bigger than a city yet shining a hundred times brighter than the Sun that send out flares of X-rays visible across the galaxy.

2.caption: Enlarge / The Vela Pulsar, a neutron star corpse left from a titanic stellar supernova explosion, shoots through space, powered by a jet emitted from one of the neutron star's rotational poles.

3707870762.given_title: New JWST image reveals full glory of Neptune, its moons, and rings
3707870762.resolved_title: New JWST image reveals full glory of Neptune, its moons, and rings
3707870762.excerpt: Scientists are wasting no time in pointing the powerful new James Webb Space Telescope all over the Universe, as well as into our own backyard. Recently, astronomers took data on the eighth planet from the Sun in our Solar System, Neptune. NASA released the first images of this world on Wednesday.

1.caption: Webb captured seven of Neptune’s 14 known moons: Galatea, Naiad, Thalassa, Despina, Proteus, Larissa, and Triton. Neptune’s large and unusual moon, Triton, dominates this Webb portrait of Neptune as a very bright point of light sporting diffraction spikes.

2.caption: Enlarge / Comparison of observations of Neptune by Voyager 2, the Hubble Space Telescope, and JWST.

2737465895.resolved_title: How Supermassive Black Holes Were Discovered
2737465895.excerpt: Astronomers turned a fantastic concept into reality.

2.caption: Figure One: Radio image of the galaxy Cygnus A. Dominating the image are two huge “lobes” of radio emitting plasma. An optical image of the host galaxy would be smaller than the gap between the lobes. The minimum energy needed to power some radio lobes can be equivalent to the total conversion of 10 million stars to energy! Note the thin trails of radio emission that connect the lobes with the bright spot at the center, where all of the energy originates. Photo from NRAO/AUI.

3.caption: Figure Two: Images of the central region of the Milky Way. The left panel shows an infrared image. The orbital track of star S2 is overlaid, magnified by a factor of 100. The orbit has period of 16 years, requires an unseen mass of 4 million times that of the sun, and the gravitational center is indicated by the arrow. The right panel shows a radio image. The point-like radio source Sgr A* is intrinsically motionless at the galactic center and, therefore, must be extremely massive. Left panel: R. Genzel; Right panel: J.-H. Zhao.

4.caption: This post originally appeared on Nautilus and was published February 7, 2019. This article is republished here with permission.Did you enjoy this story?Subscribe to Nautilus

2649265397.resolved_title: What This Drawing Taught Me About Four-Dimensional Spacetime
2649265397.excerpt: Stuck in his research, a cosmologist finds a hint in an intricate drawing.

2.caption: Light in the Garden: This drawing by the Oakes brothers, Irwin Gardens at the Getty in Winter, inspired the author to think anew about quantum mechanics and general relativity. The meticulous drawing, done on curved paper, allows viewers to reflect on the act of perception.

3.caption: Into the Distance: The Oakes’ painting Ocean Texture 2

4.caption: Electromagnetic Light Wave: This graphs shows how the electric field and magnetic field oscillate in mutually perpendicular directions.

5.caption: Light Cone: The origin, where time is zero, represents the present. The cones in the upper and lower planes represent the future and past. No information can exceed regions outside the light cone, which correspond to speeds faster than that of light.

6.caption: Circles of Light: The circles that define the Oakes brothers’ painting, Bond Street Terrace, can be seen as analogous to how light traces out a cone as it develops. The circles also create a Van Gogh-like effect of cosmic dimension.

7.caption: Spherical Waves: Green waves trace out the different points of the light cone emanating from its point of creation. The blue regions represent the time development of the spherical waves. Graphic by Brian Oakes, no relation to the artists.

8.caption: This post originally appeared on Nautilus and was published March 16, 2017. This article is republished here with permission.Did you enjoy this story?Subscribe to Nautilus

2559433888.resolved_title: Q: Why was it so hard to take a picture of a black hole? What are we even looking at?
2559433888.excerpt: Physicist: Black holes and space are both black, so there’s that.  But while black holes tend to be very small, space is bonkers big and filled with just enough stuff to give astronomers things to look at while simultaneously getting in the way of looking at said things.

1.caption: The now-famous actual picture of M87* taken in the microwave spectrum.

2.credit: as viewed from inside our galaxy
2.caption: Left: The disk of our galaxy

3.caption: The gravity of the “red blob” galaxy in the foreground, LRG 3-757, bends the light a galaxy behind it so much that it appears as a ring.  Gravitational lensing like this allows us to measure the distribution of mass by looking at how it warps the image of distant objects, and is sometimes even used intentionally

3202339896.given_title: The New History of the Milky Way | Quanta Magazine
3202339896.resolved_title: The New History of the Milky Way
3202339896.excerpt: Over the past two years, astronomers have rewritten the story of our galaxy. When the Khoisan hunter-gatherers of sub-Saharan Africa gazed upon the meandering trail of stars and dust that split the night sky, they saw the embers of a campfire. Polynesian sailors perceived a cloud-eating shark.

1.caption:
A large Milky Way–like galaxy collides with a smaller dwarf galaxy in this digital simulation. Astronomers believe that at least one major collision like this happened early in the Milky Way’s development.




Koppelman, Villalobos & Helmi

2.credit: where blue is cold and red is hot
2.caption: In these digital simulations, a Milky Way–like galaxy forms and evolves over 13.8 billion years — from the early universe to the present day. The leftmost column shows the distribution of invisible dark matter; the center column the temperature of gas

3.caption:
A simulation shows the formation and evolution of a Milky Way–like galaxy over about 10 billion years. Many smaller dwarf galaxies accrete onto the main galaxy, often becoming a part of it.




Tobias Buck

3691337602.excerpt: On September 13, 1985, Major Doug Pearson made history when he destroyed a satellite with a missile launched from his F-15. On September 13, 1985, at 12:42 p.m.

1.caption: At the White Sands Missile Range, New Mexico, in 1992, an Aries rocket launched a projectile designed to destroy incoming ballistic missiles. Later such projectiles were tested against satellites.

2.caption: The first U.S. anti-satellite weapons were air-launched ballistic missiles, including Bold Orion, carried aloft by a B-47.

4.caption: Why the F-15? Two words: power and performance. With thrust greater than weight, the fighter can climb vertically. Here, an F-15A fires two flares over Florida in 2004.

5.caption: The miniature homing vehicle—the first developed by the United States—would separate from the missile’s second stage; its infrared sensor would acquire the target.

6.caption: A model of the hit-to-kill vehicle that was carried on ASM-135.

3223831757.excerpt: Mars is many things. It's cold. It's dry. It's spectacular. It's also weird. Very, very weird.

1.caption: HiRISE camera view of strange fan-like sprays of dark material erupting from the ground near the south pole of Mars. Credit: NASA/JPL/UArizona

2.caption: Full HiRISE camera view of strange fan-like sprays of dark material erupting from the ground near the south pole of Mars. The image is about 5 km long. Credit: NASA/JPL/UArizona

3.caption: A system of radial channels carved in the Martian surface, called araneiforms, for “spider-like”. Credit: NASA/JPL/UArizona

4.caption: A schematic showing spider formation. Incoming sunlight passes through a CO2 slab to heat the ground beneath. Pressure builds, and the gas erupts into a geyser with dust in it. That material can form a broad fan in wind, or long narrow “spider legs” in calmer weather. Credit: Piqueux et al.

5.credit: using different sites at different stages in their evolution
5.caption: Possible growth of an araneiform

6.caption: The fans of material seen blown out on the Martian surface are in area where narrow channels connect together, possibly etched via erosion as gas trapped under ice flows out of cracks. Credit: NASA/JPL/UArizona
